Message.Msg: The dollar has done better under this administration than the last and real income has gone down for longer than the last 3 years. You distrust a government and think it is going to take over the very institutions that feed it, the rich and the corporations. No matter which side you think is most corrupt they are owned by and motivated by money. Next you condemn the very institutions you support and say the power has to be given back to some "individual" as if the individual can accomplish anything without banding together as a group. Unless you are looking for a strong dictator " The individual, can't build that". Even those individuals in the top 1% can't return the country to prosperity alone. There is no reason to believe they are smarter or more creative than some craftsman at the bottom of the economic scale. Unions are nothing more than "individuals" coming together so they can assert some economic power. If the union can not protect the workers then the only institution they can turn to for grievance is government which is a poor substitute for bargaining. Your illogical mutterings are all over the landscape. Yes the supreme court decision should be reversed and there should be campaign spending limits so money doesn't own the government but voting for a republican government isn't going to accomplish that. Neither party is trying to destroy the economy or the dollar. It may be that misguided beliefs like supply side economics might have that effect but it isn't because those that support it want that outcome.

Message.Title: Anybody seen the most recent Gallup/Axelrod poll? I didn't think so, here it is.
Message.Msg: President Obama’s small bounce in the polls following the Democratic National Convention has all but vanished in Tuesday’s Gallup daily tracking poll. Obama takes 47 percent support among registered voters over Romney's 46, according to the poll. Obama’s lead widened to 7 points in the days following the Charlotte, N.C., convention earlier this month, but Tuesday’s data show the race returning the level where it’s been throughout most of the contest. Prior to the conventions, Gallup’s poll had been almost completely static, with each candidate averaging 46 percent since May. The president's approval rating also dipped back below 50 percent for the first time since the convention. Forty-nine percent said they approve of the job the president is doing, compared to 45 who say they disapprove. That’s still slightly better than the last few months, when Obama hovered around break-even and occasionally dipped into negative territory. If the race is indeed returning to equilibrium, that’s welcome news for the Romney campaign, which has endured a number of high-profile missteps in recent weeks.
